awd_titl_txt: SENSORY PATHWAYS UNDERLYING NEUROPEPTIDE REGULATION OF FOOD INTAKE
awd_abstract_narration:
General Abstract

Detecting and responding to threats such as predators is critical for survival, but also interrupts feeding behaviors required to maintain energy. The brain mechanisms underlying foraging and predator avoidance trade-offs are poorly understood. This work will therefore investigate how and where within the brain threat inhibits food consumption in frogs that have a highly-developed and easily accessible neural circuitry that controls feeding. Specifically, experiments will determine how a chemical produced in the brain when animals encounter a predator disrupts the processing of sensory cues that stimulate feeding and thereby inhibits the behavior when it is not adaptive. The studies fall within US national interests in that they will help maintain our role as a leader in science and technology by advancing knowledge of how nervous systems integrate information and generate behavior, fundamental goals of neuroscience research, as well as in their potential to produce unexpected insight into anxiety-related eating disorders. The work will also impact science education through the training of students from underrepresented groups who will be recruited through existing programs at Texas Tech University, the creation of new neurophysiology laboratory exercises to complement those already developed through NSF-funded programs, and the generation of new case studies for the NSF's National Center for Case Study Teaching in Science. For outreach, the team will create a museum exhibit on sensory detection of prey and the ecology of fear at the Texas Tech Museum and provide supplies and materials related to amphibian biology, behavior and conservation to local elementary schools. 

Technical Abstract

The goal of this work is to understand neuroendocrine modulation of food intake in light of the ecological and evolutionary forces that guide optimal foraging. Specifically, the work will identify the neural mechanism(s) underlying modulation of multisensory prey capture by the stress neuropeptide corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF). In the clawed frog, Xenopus laevis, CRF rapidly inhibits prey capture through modulation within the optic tectum, an important brain area for multisensory processing of both prey and predator cues in this and other vertebrates. The PI will now determine if tectal CRF R1 receptors inhibit multisensory guided prey capture. In the first aim, pharmacological and imaging approaches will be used to test if tectal CRF R1 receptors interfere with the processing of lateral line and/or visual cues related to prey capture. In the second aim, the role of sensory afferents and inhibitory GABA+ interneurons in mediating CRF inhibition of multisensory guided prey capture will be investigated. Together, these experiments will identify the mechanisms through which an important satiety peptide interferes with a multisensory pathway required for food acquisition. The findings will broadly impact our understanding of the neuronal basis for aversive behavior and its modulation in vertebrates and possibly shed light on the evolutionary origins of disorders in which fear processing pathways are disrupted. Work associated with this proposal will also be directly incorporated into undergraduate educational experiences, in the classroom and the laboratory, and will guide the development of exhibits in the local community.

por.por_cntn:
All animals must acquire energy from food sources to grow, develop, and reproduce. Making an error in acquiring food, however, can be lethal if in the process the animal becomes vulnerable to a predator. Most animals locate and acquire food using multiple sensory modalities such as visual, smell, hearing, and vibration, and thus careful and accurate integration of multiple sensory cues is critical for survival. In addition to interpreting what an animal sees, the visual brain areas of most animals integrate information from other sensory brain areas processing auditory cues or assessing vibration.

 

While successfully finding food is critical for survival, animals must balance the search for food with watching out for predators and becoming food for someone else. The visual system of the brain makes foraging and defense decisions in order to maximize energy intake and minimize predator encounters. For example, infant monkeys will not approach food when a snake is present but, but damage to the visual part of the brain abolishes avoidance of the predator, an effect that could have lethal consequences in nature. The direct mechanisms by which this modulation of food acquisition occurs are not known.

 

Brain chemicals called neuropeptides may play a role in multisensory processing in the brain. In the mid-1990s my laboratory began examining the possibility that an appetite modulating neuropeptide called CRF is present in areas of the visual system that process multisensory cues. We showed that injecting CRF into the visual system of frogs inhibits foraging, suggesting that CRF may reduce foraging when a predator is present. Since a frog’s visual system also handles the response to vibrational cues, such as movement of the water’s surface, we wished to know whether CRF affects only vision, the response to vibrational cues, or both.

 

We developed new behavioral tests in frogs to determine whether CRF works on visual and/or vibrational cues. Injections of CRF reduced food intake in juvenile X. laevis, but these effects were specific to live prey or prey presenting olfactory and visual cues and CRF did not significantly affect the frogs response to purely visual food cues. CRF did alter the response to purely vibrational food cues. CRF inhibited the excitement of brain cells called neurons but had no direct role in altering the major inhibitory neurochemical in the brain called GABA, despite new anatomical evidence from our lab that  CRF neurons in the visual system directly contact visual system GABA neurons. We’ve also found that visual system CRF plays a very minor role in predator avoidance and discovered that a different neuropeptide called NPY has a clearer role in defensive behavior. We have recently also developed a behavioral test in which we can measure foraging and antipredator behavior at the same time to speed up our discovery of neural chemicals involved in visual system decision making. Finally, we’ve carried out work in human subjects and shown that categorically distinct stressors alter the visual attention to food cues.

 

The broader impacts for this project involved mentoring several undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral trainee, developing a lesson plan for a STEM outreach program aimed at junior high school girls, and developing a museum exhibit that was open to the public. Our museum program, entitled “To Feed or Not to Feed? What can sensory biology teach us?” involved two cohorts (n=6-20 per cohort) of middle school girls for 2.5 h per cohort per year. The planned activities were consistent with NSES standards for ‘Characteristics of organisms’ and ‘Regulation of Behavior’ (the lesson plan is available through our annual reports and photos are available on our Facebook page “Why Frogs Don't Get Fat”). We designed and developed a museum exhibit entitled “Why Frogs Don’t Get Fat: Predators, Fear and Feeding in the Wild” that took place in DaVinci’s Kitchen exhibit room (1000 sg ft space) of the Museum of Texas Tech University (Drs. Carr and Harris served as exhibit curators, Mr. Andrew Gedeon worked with us to design the exhibit). The exhibit script was divided into three main themes: predators, prey, ear and feeding to represent major topics of interest covered in our grant proposal. The exhibit consisted of 19 interactive and stationary displays and was advertised on local television and radio stations. The exhibit was kicked off by a Night at the Museum that featured public talks by Drs. Carr and Harris. Sixteen trainees (one postdoctoral, two graduate students, thirteen undergraduate research students) were mentored on the last funded proposal. We created the following website for our museum exhibit:

https://www.depts.ttu.edu/museumttu/exhibitions/2018/fear.php

The museum exhibit can be experienced online:

https://www.depts.ttu.edu/museumttu/exhibitions/2019/fear-online/index.php

Publications: We published 8 full peer-reviewed manuscripts, with two others in review and one more in preparation. We presented 17 abstracts at  meetings. We published four NSF/NSTA peer-reviewed case studies for teaching at the high school or college levels.
